goal.en:
IMPORTANT: THIS IS A NON-OBLIGATORY COURSE
SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED FOR ENGLISH 
GRADUATE STUDENTS. 
If you are not an English Graduate student, 
you will not be allowed to enroll. 
Bear in mind that no additional course cards will be 
provided to non-graduate students. 

This theory-based course concentrates on the notion of 
epistemic injustice which intersects conceptual matrices 
in the areas of epistemology, political and moral 
philosophy. 
Contemporary social epistemologists have turned their 
attention from ideal epistemic situations to quotidian 
contexts in which social identity and power play a 
significant role in the way we evaluate others’ 
statements and ours. Spaces of injustice where 
practical and theoretical knowledge is produced, 
disseminated, and assessed are not rare. 
This course seeks to provide students with 
philosophical tools to reflect on such 
spaces. To do so, we will examine two forms of 
epistemic injustice: testimonial and hermeneutical, both 
introduced by British philosopher Miranda Fricker in her 
2007 monograph Epistemic Injustice: Power and the 
Ethics of Knowing. 
We will pay attention to what is characteristic of 
them, cases illustrating them, and references preceding 
and following M. Fricker’s introduction of the terms.

outline.en:
ALL COURSE CONTENT WILL BE PROVIDED IN
ENGLISH.
Most weekly sessions comprise (i) a lecturing part; and (ii) the completion of reading, writing and speaking
exercises. Some sessions will be dedicated
to screen audio-visual material.
This three-part course is motivated by the following
questions:
Introduction: What is ‘epistemic injustice’ and how does it modify classic epistemological projects?
Section 1: What is testimonial injustice?
Section 2: What is hermeneutical injustice?

textbook.en:
A copy of the course guide will be ready on February 
19 which will comprise syllabus, handouts and reading 
material. 
Some required and optional references could be 
modified in order to comply with course discussions and 
schedule. 
The following include some of the key course 
bibliography:

Berenstain, Nora, 2016, “Epistemic Exploitation” Ergo, an Open Access Journal of Philosophy 3. 

Dotson, Kristie, 2011, “Tracking Epistemic Violence, 
Tracking Practices of Silencing” Hypatia 26(2). 

Fricker, Miranda, 2009, Epistemic Injustice: Power and 
the Ethics of Knowing, Oxford University Press.

Fricker, Miranda, Peter J. Graham, David Henderson ＆ 
Nikolaj J.L.L. Pedersen (eds.), 2021, The Routledge 
Handbook of Social Epistemology, Routledge. 

Kidd, Ian James, José Medina, Gaile Pohlhaus Jr. (eds.), 2019, The Routledge Handbook of Epistemic Injustice, 
Routledge.
